topic_name: Surface Area and Volume of Solids

canonical_explanation.text: Surface area and volume calculations are fundamental in mensuration. For cylinders, the curved surface area is 2πrh and total surface area is 2πr(r+h), while volume is πr²h. For cones, curved surface area is πrl (where l is slant height), total surface area is πr(r+l), and volume is (1/3)πr²h. For spheres, surface area is 4πr² and volume is (4/3)πr³. For hemispheres, curved surface area is 2πr², total surface area is 3πr², and volume is (2/3)πr³. When solids are combined, total surface area excludes common surfaces while volume is the sum of individual volumes. In melting and recasting problems, volume remains constant. Capacity problems involve converting cubic units to litres (1 litre = 1000 cm³).
rules: Always identify the solid shape correctly before applying formulas
For combined solids, subtract the areas of surfaces that are joined
In conversion problems, volume before melting = volume after recasting
Use π = 22/7 or 3.14 as specified in the problem
Convert units consistently (1 m³ = 1000000 cm³, 1 litre = 1000 cm³)
Slant height l = √(r² + h²) for cones
For optimization, use differentiation to find maximum or minimum values

The volume of a cone is given by which formula?
What is the surface area of a sphere with radius r?
A cylindrical water tank has a radius of 7 m and height of 10 m. What is its volume? (Use π = 22/7)
A cone has radius 3 cm and slant height 5 cm. What is its curved surface area? (Use π = 3.14)
A hemisphere has a radius of 7 cm. What is its total surface area? (Use π = 22/7)
A toy consists of a cone mounted on a hemisphere. The radius of both is 3.5 cm and the height of the cone is 4 cm. What is the total volume of the toy? (Use π = 22/7)
A metallic sphere of radius 6 cm is melted and recast into a cylinder of radius 4 cm. What is the height of the cylinder?
A cylindrical container with radius 14 cm and height 30 cm is filled with water. How many litres of water does it hold? (Use π = 22/7)

A solid is formed by joining a cylinder and a cone at their common base. If the radius is 7 cm and heights of cylinder and cone are 10 cm and 6 cm respectively, what is the total volume? (Use π = 22/7)
The curved surface area of a cylinder with radius r and height h is _____.
The slant height of a cone with radius r and height h is given by l = _____.
The volume of a hemisphere with radius r is _____.
1 cubic metre equals _____ litres.
A cylinder with radius 5 cm and height 12 cm has a volume of _____ cm³. (Use π = 3.14)
A cone with radius 7 cm and height 24 cm has a slant height of _____ cm.
A sphere with diameter 14 cm has a surface area of _____ cm². (Use π = 22/7)
A spherical ball of radius 3 cm is melted and recast into three equal smaller spheres. The radius of each smaller sphere is _____ cm.
A solid consists of a hemisphere surmounted by a cone. Both have radius 6 cm and the cone's height is 8 cm. The total surface area is _____ cm². (Use π = 3.14)
A cylindrical tank with radius 1.4 m and height 2 m can hold _____ litres of water. (Use π = 22/7)
The volume of a cylinder is directly proportional to the square of its radius.
The curved surface area of a cone is πr², where r is the radius of the base.
The volume of a sphere is greater than the volume of a hemisphere with the same radius.
In melting and recasting problems, the volume of the original solid equals the volume of the new solid.
Two cylinders with the same volume must have the same radius and height.
If the radius of a cone is doubled while keeping the slant height constant, the curved surface area doubles.
The total surface area of a hemisphere is 2πr².
When calculating the surface area of a solid formed by joining two shapes, we must exclude the area of the common surface.
A cylindrical tank with dimensions in metres will have its capacity in litres equal to its volume in cubic metres.
If a sphere is melted and recast into a cylinder with the same radius, the height of the cylinder will be (4/3)r.
